io.robusta.rra.utils

Class CoupleList<LEFT,RIGHT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractList<E>
        • java.util.ArrayList<Couple<LEFT,RIGHT>>
          • io.robusta.rra.utils.CoupleList<LEFT,RIGHT>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Couple<LEFT,RIGHT>>, java.util.Collection<Couple<LEFT,RIGHT>>, java.util.List<Couple<LEFT,RIGHT>>, java.util.RandomAccess

    public class CoupleList<LEFT,RIGHT>
extends java.util.ArrayList<Couple<LEFT,RIGHT>>

    It's just an ArrayList of Couple objects, somewhat more simple to use than regular lists of Object[2] and allowing generics :
    [(3, "Three"),(4, "44"),( 5, "cinquo"), (6, "6")] is a CoupleList<Integer, String>

    Using Hash or Couples is very convenient in Ajax world. For exemple if you want all the students of your school, you will need id (for further calls) and ScreenName for display .

    This class is designed to be more simple than fast, but anyway with correct speed.

    Author:
    Nicolas Zozol
    See Also:
    * Created by Nicolas Zozol for Robusta Code, Serialized Form

      • findMyLovers

        public java.util.ArrayList findMyLovers(java.lang.Object o)

        Returns all RIGHT elements equals to Object o when o is a LEFT element, and viceversa o can be sometimes on the left, sometime on the right.

        For exemple findMyLovers(3) in [(3,"Three"),("Not Three", 3),(4,5),(9,10)] will return ["Three", "Not Three"]

        Parameters:
        o - The object to test
        Returns:
        a list of matching objects

      • findMyFirstLoveInLeft

        public LEFT findMyFirstLoveInLeft(RIGHT o)

        Returns the first LEFT object matching the RIGHT object o

        For exemple findMyLovers(3) in [(3,"Three"),("Not Three", 3),(4,5),(9,10)] will return "Not Three"

        Returns:
        first love of o

      • findMyFirstLoveInRight

        public RIGHT findMyFirstLoveInRight(LEFT o)

        Returns the first RIGHT object matching the LEFT object o

        For exemple findMyLovers(3) in [(3,"Three"),("Not Three", 3),(4,5),(9,10)] will return "Three"

        Returns:
        first love of o

      • findMyFirstLove

        public java.lang.Object findMyFirstLove(java.lang.Object o)

        Returns the first object matching the object o, whatever if it's on the Right or the Left

        Returns:
        first love of o

      • getHashMap

        public java.util.HashMap<LEFT,RIGHT> getHashMap()

        Sometimes a CoupleList is close of a HashMap. You can get it with this function. Of course you may loose datas in your HashMap if a Left element is not Unique.

        LEFT will be the key, RIGHT the value ; use the getReversedList() function if you wish to switch.

        Returns:
        a HashMap representation of the CoupleList, with possible loss of datas.

      • reverse

        public CoupleList<RIGHT,LEFT> reverse()

        Using this function on [(3,"Three"),(4, "44"),( 5, "cinquo"), (6, "6")] will return [("Three", 3),("44", 4),( "cinquo", 5), ("6", 6)]

        You can't be confused if you use Generics.

        Returns:
        a new list, but with inverted Couples.

      • findWhere

        public CoupleList<LEFT,RIGHT> findWhere(java.lang.Object o)

        Returns the Couples where the Object o is on the LEFT OR the RIGHT.

        It returns an empty list if nothing is found. It does NOT return null.

        Parameters:
        o - Object to be found
        Returns:
        couples containing o in LEFT or RIGHT

      • findWhere

        public CoupleList<LEFT,RIGHT> findWhere(LEFT left,
                               RIGHT right)

        Returns the Couples where the left is on the LEFT AND right is on the RIGHT.

        Returns an EMPTY coupleList when can't find the couple, and nerver a NULL coupleList
        Parameters:
        left - LEFT object wanted
        right - RIGHT object wanted
        Returns:
        couples containing left in LEFT and right in RIGHT

      • removeWhere

        public void removeWhere(LEFT left,
               RIGHT right)

        This function removes all couples (left, right) from the list.

        Only couples containg left AND right elements will be removed.

        Parameters:
        left - LEFT element to test
        right - RIGHT element to test

      • removeWhere

        public void removeWhere(java.lang.Object o)
        removes all couples where o is in RIGHT or LEFT
        Parameters:
        o -

      • build

        public static <L,R> CoupleList build(java.lang.Object... x)
        Easily builds a CoupleList : CoupleList.builder(3, "Three", 4, "44", 5, "cinquo", 6, 6) will create the CoupleList :[(3, "Three"),(4, "44"),( 5, "cinquo"), (6, 6)]
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if number of params is not pair.

      • stringify

        public CoupleList<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> stringify()
        Returns a CoupleList where every objects are toString() values of initial objects
        Returns:
        a stringified CoupleList

        Considers the CoupleList as a Name/Value list. Returns null if the name is not found
        Parameters:
        name -
        ignoreCase -
        Returns:
